titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V.20. Thursday. Met S. A. Foot in the Apartment of the Committee of Commerce, upon the Sub-Committee on the Rules of the House. Wayne, the other Member of the Sub-committee did not attend, though he had promised that he would— I proposed several amendments to the Rules which we discussed till the time of the meeting of the House without coming to a conclusion— At the House, after the reading of the Journal, according to notice given yesterday I asked leave to introduce a Bill to prohibit the Corporations of Washington, Georgetown and Alexandria from issuing promissory notes of any denomination under ten dollars— The Speaker made difficulties upon the 70th. Rule, but finally my Bill was received, and at my motion referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia— This precedent will enable me hereafter if I should see fit to introduce a Bill ready prepared, upon some other subject— The distribution of all the business of the House into standing Committees has brought the introduction of Bills by individual members into total disuse; and it was not without difficulty that I obtained the permission in this case— Governor Lincoln moved a suspension of the Rule, to take up his Resolution calling upon the Postmaster General for information respecting his Clerks—rejected 93 to 63—not two thirds— Sundry other Resolutions were taken up— The Bills regulating the value of certain foreign silver coins and for extending the French and Neapolitan Commissions were ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow— The commutation pension Bill postponed till next Tuesday. The hour was expiring and Galbraith moved to postpone Mardis’s Resolution, and Corwin’s Amendment till to-morrow, and pass to the orders of the day— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the general Appropriation Bill. Hubbard in the Chair. The item of Appropriation for Ministers to Great Britain and Russia was debated on Warren R. Davis’s proviso and Foot’s motion to strike out, till 5 O’Clock and then both were rejected— The next item for Salaries for certain chargés d’Affaires gave rise to sundry questions from me to Archer the Chairman of the Committee of foreign Relations—especially respecting a proposed Chargé d’Affaires to Buenos-Ayres— Upon which the Committee rose and the House adjourned. The Senate were still in Session and before their adjournment rejected the renomination of the four Government Bank Directors Henry D. Gilpin, Peter Wager, John T. Sullivan, and Hugh M’Eldery, and removed the injunction of Secrecy from their proceedings on the subject.
2. V:30. Friday

Mr Willis of Boston came to me this morning and reminded me of old acquaintance at Haverhill— Immediately after the Meeting of the House Leonard Jarvis called up his Resolution of enquiry respecting the condition of the Banks in the District, and the causes of the breaking of several of them, upon which Thomas Chilton spoke till the expiration of the hour— Then the Bill
for making certain foreign silver coins a legal tender was read the third time, and gave rise to a debate of two hours, at the close of which R. H. Wilde moved that the Bill should be postponed till next Tuesday which was carried. A message from the President with certain proposals for amending the Laws in relation to the naval Service, prepared and reported by the board, constituted under the Act of May 19. 1832— He declares his approbation of these proposals— The rule of private business was suspended and the general Appropriation Bill, resumed in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, H. Hubbard in the Chair, and debated till near eight in the Evening when it was reported to the House— I restated my questions respecting the Chargés d’Affaires to Belgium and to the South-American Governments, seven in number, but especially to the Government of Buenos-Ayres— Archer in a speech of two hours gave a full reply, and explanations respecting them all— Not being satisfied with regard to the proposed mission to Buenos-Ayres, I moved to strike out the outfit and Salary proposed for that mission, and stated the rupture which had occurred eighteen months since, by the return home of Francis Baylies, the last Chargé d’Affaires at that place— The refusal of the President, at the last Session of Congress to communicate to the House the Instructions to F. Baylies, and the Correspondence in the Negotiation, although the Government of Buenos Ayres had published that same Correspondence, in the Spanish language, and I had received from thence a copy of it, at the very time when the President refused to send the papers to the House— The question was taken twice on my motion, once without a Quorum— The second time by Tellers, 19 to 101— The federalists voting with the Administration members, to screen from exposure and disgrace Frank Baylies, one of the rankest of their own gang—who bought his mission to Buenos-Ayres, by voting for Andrew Jackson in the House of Representatives in 1825— Who stayed at Buenos-Ayres, only a few weeks just long enough to disgrace his Country, and whom Jackson now shelters from the public contempt, by withholding the documents of his shame— Baylies after grossly insulting the Government of Buenos-Ayres, and abusing the privileges of his diplomatic character, till he was in danger of personal chastisement from the popular indignation of the place, deserted his Post and came home, without waiting for orders or Instructions— Jackson has not given him another Office—but he shields him from condign punishment by refusing the papers called for by the House— There was little debate, excepting upon this item, but several other Amendments were adopted— The House adjourned about 8 O’Clock— In the evening I had visits from Isaac C Bates and Mr Lyman of Northampton— The adjournment was at the motion of H. L. Pinckney, till Monday.
3. VI:30. Saturday

Morning visits from General Ward a member of the House from New York; and Mr Peter A. Jay, of the City of New-York, on a visit to Washington, with his family— Mr Henry Hill, heretofore Consul of the United States at St. Salvador in Brazil, and a very copious and voluminous Letter-writer to the Department of State, came and introduced himself to me, and seemed as full of matter for conversation as I found him formerly for correspondence. He returned six or eight months since from a residence of more than twenty years in Brazil; with his wife and a family of eleven children two of whom he has lost in the course of the winter, in the western part of the State of New-York; which he attributes to the climate. He said his accounts at the Treasury were settled, though on his first coming home he had found large sums, standing charged against him, as they had been many years standing, without the corresponding credits. So that he had time after time been reported as a defaulter, without knowing it, when in fact he had a claim for a balance due to him, which was now before the Committee of Claims of the House of Representatives, and for which he asked my attention when it should come before the House. I called with the Ladies
at Gadsby’s to visit Genl Stephen Van Rensselaer, and his daughters, but they had just left the City—as had also Mr Lyman— We then stop’d at Rembrandt Peale’s. He was not there, but we saw his Pictures— They were not satisfied with my Portrait— We then went to the Capitol, where I alighted and went to the Senate chamber. They were in Session—but a few minutes after, adjourned— I went into the Library, and examined Montesquieu upon the division of Powers, and the State Constitutions—and Johnson’s Life of Waller. Towards 5 O’Clock I went and dined with Alexander Porter, Senator from Louisiana at Zantzinger’s— All the Louisiana delegation, Binney and Watmough, Wilde, Marshall of Kentucky and Letcher were there— S. L. Southard after dinner— We sat till past ten at night, and I left the table and house with Binney and Watmough—walked home.
4. VI. Sunday

William C. Greenleaf left us in the Stage at half past 8 O’Clock for Baltimore, where he goes to reside— I attended morning and afternoon at St. John’s Church— Mr Hawley read the morning service for the fifth Sunday after Easter, and a stranger preached from 2. Corinthians 10.18. “For not he that commendeth himself is approved, but whom the Lord commendeth” Mrs Frye came in after Church— After dinner, another Stranger read the prayers, and a third preached from Mark 7:27. “But Jesus said unto her, let the children first be filled: for it is not meet to take the children’s bread, and to cast it to the dogs. 28. And she answered and said unto him Yes Lord: yet the dogs under the table eat of the children’s crumbs. 29. And he said unto her, for this saying, go thy way; the devil is gone out of thy daughter.”— The Convocation of Episcopal Clergy, are I suppose in Session here. Two out of three of these persons were foreigners— I think Irish. Mr Hawley baptized a boy this morning; and read a prayer for rain— It has been much needed for several weeks, and first came late this Evening. I had visits this Evening from Mr Vanderpoel member from Kinderhook New-York, of the House of Representatives, and Cornelius W. Lawrence, who came to take leave, having been recently elected, Mayor of the City of New-York—one of the most vehemently contested elections ever witnessed in this Country. His competitor was Gulian C. Verplanck, and upon upwards of 35000 votes, Lawrence had a majority of less than one hundred. I told Mr Lawrence I was very sorry to lose him, but wished him a happy and prosperous career in his new Office— I was occupied much of the leisure time of the day in addressing and in franking packets of my suppressed Speech to all the Members of the Legislature of Massachusetts, and afterwards to the Magistrates in the 12th. Congressional District.
5. VI. Monday.

Rainy night and day— At the House Gayton P. Osgood made a Speech of one hour, against the Memorial and Instructions from his own District, and then moved that they should be referred to the Committee of Ways and Means, with Instructions to report against the Resolutions— But he withdrew this motion and moved that they be laid on the table and printed. He then presented a Memorial from Boston, signed by 3200 persons against the restoration of the Deposites and the recharter of the United States Bank— I presented a Memorial from 380 citizens of Detroit in the Territory of Michigan praying for the abandonment of the experiment and the restoration of the public funds to the Bank of the United States— At my motion it was read, laid on the table and ordered to be printed with the names—Lucius Lyon, the Delegate from the Territory, assured me that the signers were highly respectable, but he said he thought the Distress had in a great degree passed away— That by his last Letters the Banks were freely discounting, and business brisk— The presentation of Petitions continued from Massachusetts; followed from Rhode Island, Connecticut,
Vermont and New-York;—D. J. Pearce presented Resolutions one of which disapproved his own votes here upon the Bank questions. Hiland Hall of Vermont made a short and pungent Speech on presenting a Memorial— W. Slade and Heman Allen also introduced Memorials with short Speeches— Several of the members of New-York presented Anti-Bank Memorials with Speeches. Selden presented one in favour of the Bank, signed by 6000 names from the County of Oneida, Beardsley’s District, and he moved that it be referred to a select Committee of one member from each State with instructions to report a Bill, and plan for a safe and uniform currency, under authority of the United States— Beardsley made a Counter-Speech, to which Selden asked leave to reply— No Quorum— The House adjourned at 1/2 past 3. Mr N. Lazell of Bridgewater had called me out and when I returned I found the House adjourned— I spent an hour in the Library reading the federalist—then walked home— Evening thunder Shower, and a visit from Miss Delia Stewart.
6. VI. Tuesday

Mrs Stewart was a visitor this morning; and a very strange accident occurred of a gilt pinchback chain necklace returned broken by mistake for a whole gold chain borrowed by Miss D. Stewart, to adorn her person at Mr White’s Fancy Ball. I called upon Mr John W Dickinson of Troy, New-York, at his Son in Law, Benjamin Ogle Tayloe’s house— Then at Gadsby’s upon Mr Peter A. Jay— Saw him and Mrs Jay— They were to leave the City this day on their return home to New-York— Next I called at Mrs Blake’s to see Mr Lazell but he had gone to the Navy-Yard— I fear his case is an immedicable consumption, to close at no distant day.— At the House, after the calling of Reports from standing and select Committees and after sundry motions, and three Resolutions of enquiry of expediency by three Committees, moved by Rice Garland of Louisiana, and adopted, Mardis’s Resolution with Corwin’s amendment was taken up, and Galbraith of Pennsylvania discoursed against the Bank of the United States until the expiration of the hour— Then the orders of the day were called and Seaborn Jones of Georgia, from the Committee of Elections, made a report on the contested Election of Robert P. Letcher, and Thomas P. Moore—in favour of Moore; and concluding with a Resolution that he is entitled to the Seat—which was read— Jones moved to postpone the consideration of the Report till next Tuesday, and that the Report and accompanying Documents be printed— Banks moved that the Evidence should also be printed, and said there would be a Report from the Minority of the Committee in two or three days. Jones opposed the printing of the Evidence, which raised a debate— Hardin and Wilde insisted upon the printing: Jones replied— The debate kindled into a blaze of personalities between Wilde, Vanderpoel and Peyton of Tennessee, and between Jones and Hardin of Kentucky— The Speaker as usual checking Jones just as he was closing his volley of invective, so as to let him have the last word and suppress Hardins final retort. After the proposal and rejection of sundry modifications, it was finally resolved that the whole Testimony should be printed, and the consideration of the Report postponed till next Tuesday.— The House adjourned after 5 O’Clock.— I gave Mr Wayne the papers left by S. A. Foot, (who has been elected Governor of Connecticut, and resigned his Seat in the House,) belonging to the Committee on the revision of the Rules of the House; which Wayne promised to return to-morrow for a Report of the Sub-Committee— I stand now in the Committee alone—one to five—quite a hopeless case. Mr Thomas F Foster of Georgia asked me for a few copies of my suppressed Speech which I promised— In the Evening Ebenezer Young a member of the House from Connecticut, called on me with a Mr Levins of that State:— In the debate of this day, Wilde raised the Storm against himself, by his apt quotation of a passage in a Letter from Horace Walpole, to Sir Horace Mann.
7. V:30. Wednesday.

John Galbraith of Pennsylvania, continued his diatribe against the Bank of the United States in fragments of a Speech upon Mardis’s Resolution, and Corwin’s Amendment till the expiration of the hour. The orders of the day were taken up; one bill passed and several others postponed. The Bill for continuing the duration of the Commission upon the claims on France gave rise to a debate— There was intelligence received this morning, that the French house of deputies 176 to 168 have refused the appropriation for satisfaction of these claims. James I. M’Kay moved to postpone the Bill till next Tuesday, and Lewis Williams moved to reduce the time of continuance of the Commission to six Months—both motions were rejected and the Bill passed— The Neapolitan Commission-Bill passed without opposition— Other Bills were postponed, and the Appropriation Bill taken up as reported by the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— The first question taken was on my Amendment to strike out the item for a new Clerk in the Department of State. L. Jarvis moved to reject this Amendment, upon which without receiving the debate I called for the yeas and nays— I was sustained, and the amendment was confirmed 90 to 62. An Appropriation for printing the Laws of the Territory of Arkansas was moved by B Hardin to be struck out; and he called for the yeas and nays. I supported the Appropriation and it was confirmed by a vote of 126 to 35— A proviso of Appropriation of 2000 dollars for a commercial agent at Algiers was after some debate struck out— Then the Appropriations for Custom-houses came and were very hotly debated till 5 O’Clock— M’Kay and D. J. Pearce objected to the Appropriations, which were sustained by John Reed, Noyes Barber Jabez W. Huntington, and Isaac M’Kim. The reductions were made as they had been voted in Committee of the whole all the adopted amendments were gone through. Mr Vance’s Amendment for reducing all the Salaries was read, and the House adjourned after an ineffectual attempt of C. F. Mercer to introduce a Resolution to adjourn over from to-morrow till Monday— At home this Evening I had visits from W. B. Calhoun, Stephen C Phillips, John Bailey and Joseph Blunt, who goes to-morrow for New-York.

8. VI. Thursday— Met at the House, William B. Calhoun, with Isaac C. Bates— Campbell P White from the Naval Committee reported a Resolution to print 1000 extra copies of the amended rules and regulations for the Navy communicated to the House by the President on the 2d. instt. The Bill N. 334 to equalize and regulate the pay of the Officers of the Army and Navy, was at the motion of Coll. Watmough recommitted to the select committee which reported it. Galbraith of Pennsylvania continued his Speech upon Mardis’s Resolution and Corwin’s Amendment till the expiration of the hour— Then the Speaker, who complained of being very unwell, placed James M. Wayne in the Chair— The Appropriation Bill was resumed, and Mr Vance supported his amendment for reducing the Salaries of the Public Officers, with a Speech of an hour— Answered by Leavitt of Ohio, and he replied. Wardwell of New-York followed, and Ewing of Indiana. Bynum of North-Carolina enlarged the sphere of Debate, by maintaining that the President had redeemed his pledges to the People of the South, by suppressing internal improvements, by reducing the Tariff, and by crushing the Bank of the United States— Governor Lincoln opposed the Amendment but declared his Approbation of the principle— Chilton replied to Bynum (interrupted by Boon) but in vain— The part of Vance’s Amendment reducing the Salaries of the Heads of Departments was rejected by yeas and nays 48 to 141—he then withdrew the part which proposed the reduction of the Salaries of the Clerks, and then asked for the yeas and nays upon a clause limiting the
Salaries of the Officers of the Customs within a Maximum— Upon this a desultory debate arose, and some confusion, till Harper of New-Hampshire, with many assurances of regret and apologies for cutting off all Amendments, moved the previous question— The main question being upon the engrossment of the Bill for a third reading— He withdrew and repeated this motion two or three times, with intervals of motions to adjourn which failed. He finally moved the previous question, and declared he would not withdraw it. Question taken by Tellers and failed. 63 to 101. The motion to adjourn, then near 6. O’Clock prevailed by a small majority— Mr Mercer agreed to postpone his motion to adjourn over to Monday till next Thursday— Idle Evening— Harmar Denny shewed me several Resolutions adopted at an Anti-mason’s Meeting at Pittsburgh, which he is requested to present to the House.

9. VI. Friday. Immediately after the reading of the Journal it appeared there was no quorum in the House—and a motion was made to adjourn. The yeas and nays were called— The object was to attend the Race-grounds, where numbers of the members were in actual attendance. The motion was rejected 12 to 118. The first hour was absorbed by the introduction of sundry motions and resolutions. C. P. White’s motion for printing 1000 copies of the newly reported Rules and Regulations for the Navy was adopted— Banks of Pennsylvania presented the Report of the minority of the Committee of Elections (3. Claiborne, Banks and Griffin) on the contested election between Letcher and Moore— At Noon the House passed to the orders of the day, and by suspending the Rules for private business, took up the general Appropriation Bill Mr Vance’s Amendment, limiting within a maximum the compensation of the Collectors, Naval Officers and Surveyors of the Customs was resumed and after some discussion adopted by yeas and nays 85 to 72. White of Florida, then renewed and modified his motion for allowances to two judges in Florida, which after much debate was adopted. Sutherland renewed a motion to extend and secure Salaries to the Collector, Naval Officers and Surveyors, equal to what they were in 1832. and started a long debate. Vance moved as an Amendment to the Amendment, that the Secretary of the Treasury should dismiss 121. Clerks and other Officers from the custom-house at New-York. So these succeeded proposals of other Amendments and desultory debates; yeas and nays repeatedly taken. Motions of Adjournment, calls of the House, and for the previous question— Upon a sharp debate on the condition of the Post-Office, this was finally put, on motion of Cave Johnson, and upon a count by Tellers there were 76 ayes (after a refusal to call the House,) The minority defeated this attempt by abstaining to vote, in numbers sufficient to make a Quorum— Cave Johnson withdrew his motion for the previous question and the debate was renewed— At half past one in the morning the vote to engross the Bill for a third reading was taken and carried and the House adjourned over to Monday.
10. VII. Saturday.

A Session of nearly fifteen hours, without intermission and without refreshment, exhausted me so much that on returning home, I merely took a plate of soup, a small piece of bread and half a glass of water, upon which I went immediately to bed and slept soundly till seven— This morning I called at the Office of the Secretary of War with a Letter in behalf of the heirs of Swanzy Hart a Revolutionary Soldier for a claim of bounty Lands. Mr Cass took minutes of the name, and promised to make enquiries and let me know the result— I spoke to him of the recent intelligence from France, of the refusal of the Chamber of deputies to grant the supplies of 25 Millions of Francs stipulated for indemnities of the claims of Citizens of the United States for spoliations committed during the War, and the reign of Napoleon. I enquired if official information of the refusal had been received. He said there had been
despatches received from Mr Livingston yesterday; and that the case was worse than the report had indicated— It was now stated as a strong suspicion that the refusal of the chamber of deputies to appropriate was instigated by the Kings Ministry themselves— Which I thought quite improbable— I had some conversation with Mr Cass respecting the obligation of Treaties. I visited at Gadsby’s Mr Stephen C. Phillips whom I found confined by indisposition to his chamber with some fever. He mentioned to me that he contemplated going out to India, upon a commercial expedition— I dined with Mr William Baylies—D. Webster and N. Silsbee; I. C. Bates, Gorham, Grennell and Reed—W. C. Calhoun and General Wool constituted the company— There was much conversation, of which I should have taken an undue proportion, but that Benjn Gorham preferred taking it to himself; to which I readily yielded— Gorham’s views upon all controverted subjects are original and ingenious— I had always rather hear him than discourse myself— Mr Webster withdrew soon after dinner. The rest of the company sat till near ten— Mrs Adams, very unwell—

11. VI. Sunday. Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith from Isaiah 55.6. “Seek ye the Lord while he may be found; call ye upon him while he is near!” Mrs Frye was here After dinner at St Johns Church Mrthe Clergyman from New-Brunswick read the Evening service for the Sunday after Ascension day, and Mr Hawley preached from Luke 19.40. “And he answered, and said unto them, I tell you, that if these should hold their peace, the stones would immediately cry out.” Mr Hawley announced that the Communion would be administered next Sunday, which is Whitsunday; and Mr Smith gave notice that he should be absent the two succeeding Sundays.— The remainder of the day, I was engaged in the endeavour to recover the regular order of my ideas and occupations. I was not very well, and Mrs Adams was quite ill with a turn of Erisypelas. Wrote a Letter to my Son Charles, and franked numerous copies of my suppressed Speech to the Justices of Peace in Massachusetts— Looking over my files of Letters I found a multitude of them unanswered: no small number which ought to be answered, but for which I shall never find time; and a few to which answers are indispensable. Among the rest are the following, from Seth Sprague jr. Duxbury 25. Feby 1834—Bill for the relief of P. Sprague—and T. P. Beal. Kingston 21. April 1834. Bill for relief of Ebenr Lobdell.
12. VI. Monday.—

Mr Southey Parker whose petition had at his request, and upon my motion been transferred from the Committee of Naval Affairs to the Committee of Claims, came and enquired of me what had been done with it— I promised to enquire of Mr Whittlesey, and to inform him to-morrow morning. Mr Kervand a French confectioner and keeper of a boarding house came and told me that Baron Stackelberg the late Swedish Chargé d’Affaires, had left this Country owing him 1000 dollars for board and lodging; and that Mr Krehmer, the Secretary of the Russian Legation, now owed him 2000 dollars for the same objects, for which he was unable to obtain payment; and he asked me for advice— I advised him to write to C. Hughes, and request him upon his return to Stockholm to obtain payment of the demand against Baron Stackelberg, and to apply to the Secretary of State for his interference, in the case of the demand against Krehmer. At the House, on Polk’s motion, the rules for receiving Memorials and Petitions, on the first meeting day of the week, were set aside for the 3d. reading of the general Appropriation Bill, which was passed— The Army Appropriation Bill came from the Senate with an Amendment— The House went into Committee of the whole, George M. Briggs in the Chair, the amendment was adopted, and reported to the House and the Bill was passed. Then the Memorials were taken up, and a disputation was held between Dudley Selden and
Samuel Beardsley, upon a memorial from Oneida County— Selden had offered a Resolution for the appointment of a Committee of one member from each State, to enquire into the expediency, and report upon the establishment of a National Currency. John W. Brown moved to lay the whole on the Table, which was carried by the casting vote of the Speaker. Yeas and Nays 90 to 90. Sharp altercation between the two members from the State of Mississippi, Plummer and Cage— The presentation of Memorials proceeded only from New-York to Pennsylvania, when there was found no Quorum, and at half past 3. the House adjourned. The Senate were in Executive Session. Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening.
13. V.45. Tuesday.

Mr Parker came this morning to enquire concerning the state of his claim before the House, of which I was not able to inform him. He said the watchmen at the Navy Department were much distressed at the increase of pay allowed by the general Appropriation Bill to the Watchmen of the War Department, without corresponding augmentation to them— At the House, the Testimony annexed to the Report of the Minority of Elections in the case of Letcher and Moore was on the Tables of the Members,—a volume of 727 pages. Seaborn Jones moved that the consideration of the subject be postponed till next Tuesday, which was carried without a division— Henry A. Wise, presented a Memorial from York, and adjacent Counties in Virginia, praying Congress to carry into effect the Resolution of the Congress of the Revolutionary War, of 29. October 1781. for the erection of a marble monument of the Surrender of Cornwallis— The Memorial was referred to a Select Committee of five—Henry A. Wise—J. Q. Adams, Philemon Thomas, Henry L. Pinckney and John Murphy. Wise presented also a Memorial from Gloucester County, Virginia, protesting against the removal of the deposits, and praying for their restoration; which Wise moved should be referred to a Select Committee of seven to be chosen by ballot, with instructions to report his three Resolutions asserting the power of Congress over the custody of the public monies, and also to report all necessary measures for protecting this power of Congress— The consideration of this Memorial and Motion was postponed till next Monday— The Speaker laid before the House, a Letter from the Secretary of State, informing the House, that the Diplomatic Correspondence from the Peace of 1783 to the 4th. of March 1789. has been printed, according to the act of 5. May 1832. and that 965 sets of 7. volumes 8vo. are at the disposal of Congress— Also two Letters from the Secretary of War, in answer to Calls, and a Letter from S. A. Foot dated New-Haven 9. May 1834. informing the Speaker that he had, on that day, resigned his Seat as a member of the 23d. Congress.— Boon of Indiana called up the Resolution offered by him on the 5th. of April for the adjournment of Congress on Saturday the 31st. of May.— He asked the suspension of the Rules and the yeas and nays which were 150 to 13.— He then moved by way of modification, Monday 16. June for the day of adjournment and asked the yeas and nays which were ordered. Propositions were made to change the day to the preceding Saturday and the succeeding Tuesday, and rejected. Enquiry was then made of Polk if he intended to bring forward his forty Bank’s Bill, this Session. He said he did, immediately after the passage of the remaining Appropriation Bills— The hour elapsed and the House passed to the orders of the day. Boon read a paragraph from a Newspaper, purporting to be a Letter from a member of the House, reflecting upon him for offering the Resolution, and pronounced it a calumnious falsehood. Polk made an effort to get up one of the Appropriation Bills, but failed— The
commutation revolutionary Pension Bill being the special order of the day, and it was discussed by Crane of Ohio, Heman Allen of Vermont, Fulton of Virginia and Young of Connecticut—Gilmer of Georgia, Vanderpoel and Wise— Gilmer moved the recommitment of the Bill, to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union which was carried. 84 to 76. Evening visits from Elisha Whittlesey, with Messrs. Whittlesey, Johnson and another from Ohio—from William B. Lawrence of New-York, and from Dr John Codman of Dorchester. G. W. Lay, invited me to dine with him to-morrow.
14. VI. Wednesday.

Mr Parker came again about his claim, for additional compensation as Superintendent of the Navy Department building, and the claim of increased compensation to the watchmen of that building to keep even pace with those of the War Department— He said Mr Kane has promised to see to it in the Senate— Morning visits from Mr Lay, with Mr Cary a member of the Senate of New-York and his Son— At the House the Letter, received yesterday from the Secretary of State, relating to the printing of the Supplementary Diplomatic Correspondence from 1783 to 1789. was at the motion of Wayne referred to the Committee on the Library. Galbraith continued through the first hour his Speech on Mardis’s Resolution and Corwin’s amendment— Then Boon of Indiana gave notice that he should to-morrow call up for consideration his Resolution for the adjournment of Congress on the 16th. of June. Then upon the motion of Polk Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, by unanimous consent the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Speight of North-Carolina in the Chair, upon the Indian Appropriation Bills. First the Bill N. 109 making Appropriations for the Indian Department for the year 1834. This Bill was passed through the Committee, almost without debate— Then the Bill 182. making Appropriations for Indian annuities, and other similar objects for the year 1834. Many amendments were proposed to this Bill, which were variously debated. An amendment was proposed applying 112000 dollars deposited in the War Department, the capital belonging to the Seneca Tribe of Indians, to the payment of all the annuities in the Bill: to which I objected as a violation of good faith, by disposing of the property belonging to the Indians, and of which the President of the United States is the Trustee— The Amendment was however adopted 67 to 59. The Bill was further debated till 5. O’Clock, when the Committee rose and reported both the Bills with Amendments, and the House adjourned. Augustin S. Clayton of Georgia, brought me his daughter’s Album with a request that I would write my name in it— Two Messages were received from the President with copies of the Treaties, with the King of the two Sicilies, 14. October 1832—ratifications exchanged at Naples 8. June 1833. and with the Emperor of Russia. 2/13 December 1832. ratifications exchanged at Washington 11. May 1833— A Letter from the first Comptroller of the Treasury and two from the Secretary of War were also laid before the House by the Speaker. Hawes moved a reconsideration of the vote by which the commutation Pension bill was yesterday recommitted to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union— I dined with Mr G. W. Lay at his lodgings. Mr Cary, a member of the Senate of New-York with his wife and Son were there— Mr and Mrs Frelinghuysen, Mr and Mrs Burges and their Son, Mr and Mrs Huntington, Mr Knight the Senator from Rhode-Island, and Dr Naudain Senator from Delaware John Connell came in after dinner.
15. VI. Thursday

Lines to Miss Almira Clayton, in her Album— Southey Parker came to enquire about his claims, and those of the watchmen of the Navy Department. He shewed me the Letter from the Secretary of War, to the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, recommending the increase of the War Department
Watchmen’s pay; and the Letter from the Navy Department Watchmen— At the House Ratliff Boon called up his Resolution for the adjournment of Congress on the 16th. of June. and Cambreleng, after the rule was suspended by yeas and nays 126 to 23. and after Ben. Hardin had proposed to amend the Resolution by substituting the 30th. for the 16th of June, moved the postponement of the subject to this day fortnight, which after a debate of 3 hours, was carried by yeas and nays 116 to 98— The vote for the postponement was carried by the administration members with about 20 others— The opposition to the number of about 75 voting against the postponement— A Message was received from the President with a copy of a Treaty with Chili, concluded at Santiago de Chili 1. September 1833. ratifications exchanged at Washington 29. April last.— The Speaker laid before the House a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury and one from the Secretary of the Navy: The Bill making Appropriations for the Indian Department was passed for engrossment, with the amendments adopted in Committee of the whole save one. The House then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hubbard who was acting as Speaker, sent to enquire if I would take the chair, and immediately after called me to it— The Cumberland Road Bill, which had passed the Senate was first taken up, and laid aside, no amendment to it being offered, but M’Kay of North-Carolina, announcing his intention to offer one. The Harbour Bill was then taken up, Hubbard acting upon it as Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means— An item of 50000 dollars for removing obstructions from the Savannah River occasioned some debate, and there was more on an amendment of twelve items for harbours, along the whole line of the western lakes— The debate thereon continued until past 5. when the Committee rose at the motion of John M’Kinley without reporting either Bill, and the House adjourned. Mr Wise notified a meeting at ten O’Clock to-morrow morning of the Committee, on the Memorial from York Town, for the erection of a marble column there to commemorate the surrender of Cornwallis.
16. VI. Friday.

At ten O’Clock this morning, I attended at the room of the Committee of Commerce the Select Committee on the York-town Monument Memorial. Wise, Thomas of Louisiana, Pinckney and Murphy— All present except Pinckney. The memorial from York-town asks an appropriation of 20000 dollars, to carry into effect a Resolution of the Confederation Congress of 29. October 1781— After some conversation I was charged to prepare and report to the Committee a Bill— In the House Galbraith after consuming the first hour in continuation of his Speech upon Mardis’s Resolution and Corwin’s Amendment, asked five minutes more to conclude. The rule was suspended and he spoke another full hour— Stewart then moved to lay the Resolution on the table, without recollecting that the question before the House was upon Corwin’s Amendment, upon which we were desirous of obtaining a direct vote— The rule at Boon’s motion was suspended to enable Stewart to make the motion to lay the Resolution on the Table— He made and after some discussion withdrew it— M’Dowell Moore, immediately renewed it, and I made it a question of order, whether the suspension of the Rule extended to authorise other members to renew the motion, when the mover had withdrawn it.— Hubbard who was in the Chair as Speaker decided that it did not, upon which a debate of two hours arose, on several questions of order, till Hubbard reversing his first decision, decided, that under the suspension of the rule, for one member to make a motion, if it be withdrawn, by him, it may be renewed by another— From this decision I appealed—after some debate Moore withdrew his motion and the question occurred whether my appeal, fell with the withdrawal of Moore’s motion— Hubbard decided that it did not, Van Houten repeated the motion
to lay the Resolution and Amendment on the table, and the House confirmed Hubbard’s decision against my appeal by a vote of 150 to 13— Corwin then withdrew his Amendment, after a debate upon it of more than four months—that is upon Mardis’s Resolution, which he also withdrew— Vance had moved a reconsideration of the suspension of the rule, at Boon’s motion, but the House refused to reconsider— The Indian Department Appropriation Bill was ordered to be engrossed for a third reading, and the House at the motion of Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hubbard acting as Speaker called me to the Chair— The Cumberland Road Bill and the Harbour Bill, were successively debated till past 5. when the Committee rose without decision upon either of them.— Thompson of Ohio, moved a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday postponing the consideration of Boon’s resolution for adjournment on the 16th. of June, for a fortnight and then moved that his motion should be postponed till next Tuesday— Pending this Question the House adjourned— Mr Bailey was here this Evening.
17. VI. Saturday.

Mr Hassler called upon me this morning, and shewed me his Charts of triangulation of the Coast which he made the last Season; but from what he said I understood he had got into difficulties again with the Treasury Department about his compensation— He said he could not continue the work unless they would make him some allowance for his labours on the Weights and Measures or an increase of compensation for the Survey— At the House Richard M. Johnson made from the Committee on Military Affairs a report in favour of the continuance of the Military Academy at West Point—ordered to lie on the table— Watmough, from the Committee to which the army and navy pay regulation Bill was recommitted, reported an amended Bill to regulate the pay of the Navy, with a further written report—committed to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Pinckney from the Committee of Commerce, reported a Bill in addition to the act of 13. July 1832. concerning tonnage duty on Spanish vessels—with a report— The Bill was twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Thompson of Ohio’s motion for reconsideration of the postponement for a fortnight of the consideration of Boon’s resolution to adjourn on the 16th. of June— Thompson had moved yesterday that his own motion for reconsideration should be postponed till next Tuesday, the day fixed for considering the contested Kentucky election. This morning Thompson modified his motion of postponement of his own Resolution, substituting next Thursday instead of Tuesday for taking it up— Evans of Maine moved that the motion for reconsideration be laid on the Table, which the House by yeas and nays refused 77 to 86—whereupon Thomson himself withdrew his motion— R. M. Johnson asked if this could be done. The Speaker answered yes— Johnson asked if another member could not renew the motion. The Speaker said no—it was too late— This decision was directly in the face of that of Hubbard yesterday, confirmed by an almost unanimous vote of the House against my appeal. But R. M. Johnson now acquiesced without appealing. My Resolution then came up, offered 28. March, calling for information from the Secretary of the Treasury, relating to the unavailable funds and the depository Banks— I withdrew the part relating to the unavailable funds, a Report of them having been made at the last Session of Congress— The discussion upon the other part of my Resolution had barely commenced when noon came, and the orders of the day were called for— The House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and the Speaker called me to the Chair— The Cumberland Road Bill—N. 79. and the Harbour Bill 269. after some debate the Cumberland Road Bill was reported to the House without amendment, and the Harbour Bill with sundry Amendments— At the motion of C. F. Mercer, the Rules were suspended for him to offer a Resolution that Thursday
next, to give time to remove the carpet from the floor, and lay the matting, and to ventilate and purify the Hall, the House will adjourn over till the succeeding Monday—which was adopted— There was another reason for the motion— To give some of the members the opportunity for an excursion to Harper’s Ferry.

18. VI. Sunday.— Heard at the Presbyterian Church, this morning Mr Smith, who gave notice that there would be no afternoon service there—in consequence of the quarterly Sunday School Union, to be held this afternoon at Dr Lowrie’s Church— I attended there and took my Son John’s daughter Mary-Louisa with me. The house as usual was exceedingly crowded— The meeting was opened by Dr Lowrie— Then a prayer by Obadiah B. Brown, the Baptist Minister, Clerk and accountant at the Post-Office, and otherwise and more appropriately qualified by the late Coll. John Tayloe— No pulpit can without disgrace open its doors to him; and the sight and hearing of him almost sickened me with quarterly Sunday School meetings. It is a scandal to hear such men as him and Ephraim K. Avery pronounce the name of God, in prayer. He was followed by the Revd. Mr Hatch, Chaplain to the Senate with an extemporaneous Address to the children of the Schools, well adapted to their capacities, and seasoned by a Story of a poor bad boy, reformed by attendance on Sunday Schools, and the instruction received at them. The Attorney General, Benjamin F. Butler then delivered an Address to the Teachers, containing judicious advice with regard to the mode of giving instruction; rather long, but not altogether ineloquent— Then Mr Theodore Frelinghuysen, a Senator from the State of New-Jersey, addressed the auditory generally, and the Parents of the children attending the Sunday Schools, upon the benefits of such Institutions, with a tribute of Eulogy upon their founder Raikes.— A hymn was then sung, and the meeting was dissolved, by Dr Laurie. The ceremonies were of nearly three hours duration and the heat of the weather was so oppressive that after returning home I was unable to write— I had already attended three or four of these quarterly meetings, which are all much alike— The Addresses were this day less interesting than I had ever found them before: whether from the infection of Obadiah B Brown’s share in them, or from an unusual infusion into them of the Spirit of dulness, I leave for future consideration.
19. VI. Monday.

Mr Parker came again to enquire into the state of his claims, and those of the watchmen of the Navy Department— He had a copy of a Letter from the Secretary of the Navy in favour of the Watchmen. Mr Choate with three other visitors from Salem and Boston, and Judge Peter O. Thacher called upon me. At the House, Watmough told me that Stevenson the Speaker had given him private notice that he should resign the Chair to-morrow. He is to be nominated to the Senate this day, as Minister to Great-Britain— A multitude of Petitions and Memorials were presented— The memorial from Savannah, against the restoration of the deposites was laid on the table— John Dickson of New-York; upon a Memorial from the County of Ontario, against the removal of the deposites, and in favour of the United States Bank made a Speech of two hours and a half— The Memorial from Gloucester, Virginia, presented last Tuesday by Wise, and motion for a Select Committee, and proposed Resolutions, were at his motion postponed till next Monday— Then Joseph B. Anthony of Pennsylvania made a Speech of an hour against the Bank of the United States, upon a memorial from the County of Lycoming which he presented last Monday—and closed by moving that the memorial be laid on the table, and printed— Sundry Memorials then followed till Beaumont of Pennsylvania presented a Memorial from the State of Mississippi on the Bank, and
the Deposites— Plummer moved that it should be postponed until next Monday; upon which a division was called for, and the postponement was refused. Plummer then prepared to make a Speech now— Briggs asked if a member from one State could present a petition or memorial from another— The Speaker said yes— Finally Beaumont withdrew the Memorial— M’Kim of Baltimore presented a paper signed by many of his Constituents of the first five wards of that city—instructing him to vote for the restoration of the deposites and the recharter of the United States Bank—laid on the table— The course of Petitions was resumed and gone through till between 5 and 6. when the house adjourned— A Letter was read from Cornelius W. Lawrence; now Mayor of the City of New-York, dated there the 14th. and resigning his Seat as a member of the House— I took from the Clerk, the papers of the claim of Southey Parker, for increase of compensation, which M’Intire had returned, and got the Committee of Claims discharged from the consideration of them; and I carried them to the Senate and gave them to Mr Silsbee, asking him to deliver them to Mr Webster, Chairman of the Committee of Finance.
20. V. Tuesday.

Immediately after the reading of the Journal, the Speaker announced the Report on the contested Kentucky Election— At the motion of Elisha Whittlesey, the Reports of Committees ready to be presented were first received— Then Seaborn Jones called for the reading of the Report of the Majority of the Committee, closing with a Resolution, declaring Thomas P. Moore entitled to the Seat— Objection was made, but the House, by a small majority decided that it should be read— It was accordingly read, and Jones offered a Resolution that Letcher and Moore should be admitted to support their respective claims to the Seat before the House— Banks moved that the minority Report should be read— This was loudly objected to, till the yeas and nays were called for, and agreed to be taken, when the objection was withdrawn— It was read, and Banks made a Speech in support of it, and offered a Resolution declaring that certain votes, struck out from Letcher’s poll, by the majority of the Committee, ought to be counted for him; and announced his intention to offer a Series of similar Resolutions, relative to the votes withdrawn from Letcher upon other principles— Banks moved that the Report should be committed to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union—this the House refused by yeas and nays 84 to 106. Jones replied to Banks in a long Speech. Marshall of Kentucky followed Jones, and spoke about an hour, when before he had finished, the House adjourned. Horace Everett, from the Committee on Indian Affairs, made a long Report—with three Bills. 488. 489. 490.— Ten thousand copies of the Report were ordered to be printed— On motion of Christopher Tompkins the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions were discharged from the further consideration of the case of Relief Harris, and it was laid on the Table— I went into the Senate chamber, and spoke to Mr Webster upon Southey Parker’s claims— We had company to dine, as per margin. C. Hughes went off for Baltimore at ten this Evening. The weather has turned to summer heat. As our company for dinner were assembling, Mr William Churchill of New-York came with a recommendatory Letter from Dr. Zaccheus Bartlett— He is a Son of Solomon Churchill, a claimant of a Pension for service in the Revolutionary War, in whose behalf I have repeatedly and unsuccessfully applied at the War Department— Mr Churchill has with him some additional testimony. I promised to go with him to-morrow Morning, and introduce him to the Secretary of War.
21. V:30. Wednesday.

Mr Churchill called upon me, and I went with him and introduced him to the Secretary of War, and to James L. Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions— At the House the Speaker merely opened the sitting; announced the Kentucky election as the subject before the House, and immediately placed Henry Hubbard in the Chair— Mr Mercer came to my Seat, and invited me to go on the party to Harper’s ferry by the Canal on Friday; to return on Saturday— A Message was received from the President of the United States by Asbury Dickins, Chief Clerk in the Department of State— He brought a copy of a Convention with her Catholic Majesty (Spain) for the settlement of claims; concluded at Madrid the 17th. of February last—ratified here; but not yet in Spain— Thomas A. Marshall finished his Speech on the Kentucky Election, in two hours—followed by Augustin S. Clayton, one hour—then Ben Hardin an hour. Then a division was called of the question upon the Amendment offered by Mr Banks, and it was agreed that the question should be taken by yeas and nays. Jones of Georgia replied to Marshall, Clayton and Hardin. Just as the yeas and nays were about to be taken Hamer of Ohio took the floor, and at the motion of Lytle the House adjourned at four O’Clock— I was going into the Senate chamber but they also had adjourned— Andrew Stevenson was nominated this morning to the Senate, as Minister Plenipotentiary to Great Britain, and Mahlon Dickerson as Minister to Russia— After dinner this Evening, I walked with Mrs Adams to the House of Mr W. S. Smith, but neither he, nor Mrs Smith was at home— On our return we found Dr Huntt had been called in to Mrs Good’s daughter Mary suddenly seized with violent convulsion fits. They continued with extreme severity till past one O’Clock in the Morning.

22. V:30. Thursday. Mrs Good’s daughter was again seized with convulsion fits and Dr Huntt was again called in— They were extremely violent, and the Doctor thought for some time that she could not survive them.— Towards evening however they subsided. At the House, by a Resolution reported by Chinn, Chairman of the District Committee, and amended at the motion of Lewis Williams, Chairman of the Committee on the Territories, Thursday the 5th. of June next, was set apart for the consideration of Bills relating to the Territories, and Friday and Saturday, the 6th. and 7th. of June for the consideration of Bills in relation to the District of Columbia. Elisha Whittlesey, from the Committee of Claims reported a Bill for the relief of Major George Bender—twice read—referred to the Committee of the whole House, and made the order of the day for to-morrow— Wayne, with leave offered a Resolution, authorising the Librarian of Congress, to deliver to each member of the present, but not the last Congress, two copies of the returns of the last Census, and that the members be authorised to transmit them free of postage by mail— It was a joint resolution, twice read, and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow— Connor from the Committee on Post-Offices and Post-roads, reported the annual Post-road Bill, which was twice read and committed to the Committee of the whole House to-morrow— On the motion of Wayne, 2000 extra copies were ordered to be printed of the report of the Committee on the compensation of the Officers of the Navy— The use of the Hall was at the motion of C. C. Cambreleng, granted for a meeting next Monday Evening, for the benefit of the Polish exiles— About three quarters of the first hour, were by consent allowed to receive reports of Committees, and these and sundry other Resolutions— The Message from the President, received yesterday with the Spanish Convention was read and referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— Then came the Kentucky Election and a Speech of Hamer, of an hour and a half—followed by
H. Binney, on the other side, in one of his close, argumentative lawyer-like Speeches the debate was then suspended to receive the Reports of the Bank-investigating Committee—that of the majority of the Committee (Thomas of Maryland, Muhlenberg—Mason of Virginia, Mann of New-York and Lytle) was made by Thomas the Chairman, and that of the minority (Everett and Ellsworth) by Edward Everett. The consideration of both the Reports was postponed till Tuesday the 3d. of June— When the debate on the Reports of the Committee of Elections was resumed, Clayton of Georgia moved to adjourn, which the House by yeas and nays refused 92 to 86.— Miller of Pennsylvania moved to postpone till next Tuesday, but on a call for yeas and nays withdrew the motion, and moved to lay the report on the table— The yeas and nays were again called for, and again Miller withdrew his motion— It was half-past 4 O’Clock, and M’Kinley moved to adjourn. a Question was made whether the motion was in order, no question having been taken since the house had refused to adjourn. Hubbard acting Speaker decided that the motion was in order, because there had been debate on a question to postpone, since the decision against Clayton’s motion— The adjournment was now carried by yeas and nays 91 to 88. and after 5 O’Clock the House adjourned over to Monday.
23. V. Friday.— Excursion to Harper’s Ferry.

I was up this morning before 5. O’Clock and my Son John went with me over to Georgetown, to the landing place of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. There we found two Canal boats, one of them of Cast-Iron— They were filled with a company, chiefly of members of Congress; and a few of them had their families with them; all invited by the President and Directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company to make an excursion to Harper’s Ferry. My Son left me at the landing place and returned home. I entered the largest of the two Boats, which was full of company: among whom a small number of Ladies— The band of musick of the Marine Corps were also there, distributed in the two boats— Mr Charles F. Mercer late President of the Corporation, and the real founder of the whole undertaking was of the Company; John P. van Ness, Mayor of Washington, Mr Coxe of Georgetown, and Coll. Abert a Director on the part of the Government, did the honours of the party— The passage on the Canal was very slow, and continually obstructed by stoppage of the Locks. Of these there are thirty-four, between Georgetown, and Harper’s Ferry— There was a light collation and dinner and after it some drinking of strong wine, which made some of the company loquacious and some drowsy. The Band gave occasional reports of animating instrumental musick— The Canal almost the whole way follows close upon the course of the Potowmac river: the country along the margin of which is general beautiful, sometimes wild, and in other parts variously cultivated, but seemingly little inhabited— There is not a luxuriously comfortable Country Seat, on the whole way— Nor one that bespeaks affluence and taste— The point of Rocks is one of the remarkable positions on the way— We reached Harper’s Ferry about 9 in the Evening, and with the aid of Mr Mercer, and of the agent of the corporation I was quartered in the House of General Rust, the Superintendant of the National Armoury of this place. The Ladies and daughters of several members of Congress, were also provided with the same place for lodging— All were hospitably received by General Rust and his Lady— But it was about midnight when I got to bed.
24. V. Saturday. Day at Harper’s Ferry.

The company lodged here consist of Mr and Mrs George R. Gilmer of Georgia Mr. and Mrs William K. Clowney of South Carolina, Mrs Seaborn Jones with her daughter, and a niece Miss Grantland—Miss Gamble, daughter of Roger L. Gamble, a member of the House from Georgia—Mr Jones and Mr Gamble taking lodgings at the Inn— I was by special favour quartered in the same house with the Ladies— We all breakfasted
with General Rust’s family— Mr and Mrs Leonard Jarvis were quartered in another house, and the other members of Congress to the number of about forty, found entertainment at the Inn— After breakfast, all the company made an excursion up the river two or three miles as far as the canal has been completed, and down the river nearly to the point of Rocks— At One O’Clock we all dined together at the Inn, and after dinner first visited the Armoury, where the Rifles are made, but the works are not comparable to those at Springfield. We then ascended the Hill, which overlooks the village, and rested at the residence of Captain John P. Hall. Here we saw the junction of the Potowmac and Shenandoah Rivers, described somewhat enthusiastically by Mr Jefferson— I went to the hanging rock that bears his name, and observed the double range of precipitous rocky hills between which the river flows— It has some resemblance on a much smaller scale to the course of the Elbe between Dresden, and the borders of Bohemia. There is not much of the sublime in the Scene, and those who first see it after reading Mr Jefferson’s description are usually disappointed— We met on the Hill Mr John Petre, who resides in that vicinity. In the Evening there was a large party at General Rust’s, of all the company from Washington, and of Gentlemen, living in the Neighbourhood. The Band was stationed in the entry; and the Ladies performed on the Piano, and sung— The party continued till near Midnight, and it was agreed that we must all be on board the Boats to-morrow morning at five O’Clock; to depart upon our return to Washington— The weather has been very warm and dry— There was this afternoon an appearance of an approaching thunder-storm, but it passed off.
25. IV:30. Sunday— Return from Harper’s Ferry to Washington.

At five O’Clock this morning our Company reassembled at the Landing, and embarked in the two Canal Boats upon the return from our excursion— About ten miles from Harper’s ferry we landed and breakfasted at a Public House where notice had been given to be prepared to receive and provide for us. We then re-embarked and proceeded upon our return. The heat of the weather was great and retarded the pace of the horses, by which the boats were drawn till a heavy thunder shower and gust came up about four in the afternoon. There was some occasional change of the company. Some of the passengers passing from one boat to the other. Albert G Hawes a member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky made himself very amusing to the company by facetious humours and coarse jokes, and a very frequent and copious consumption of whisky drams. He talked much more than his share, sometimes to the great entertainment, and sometimes to the no small distaste of the Company— In the height of the thunder shower, I and many others of the Passengers landed at a Lock, and took refuge from the rain in a neighbouring house. After the thunder shower, the rain continued at intervals all the Evening, which was very dark. The Ladies retired into a small cabin, very narrow, and to my great surprise sung with great facility a variety of methodistical hymns. It was past midnight, when we arrived at the landing at Georgetown, where my Coachman Wilson, and the coloured Man Ball were waiting for me with the Barouche, and had been waiting from 5 in the afternoon. I returned immediately home, and was safe in bed about one in the Morning— Among our Company was judge Peter O. Thacher of the Municipal Court at Boston— Members of the House of Representatives from all parts of the Union, but only one member of the Senate, Mr M’Kean of Pennsylvania— I have been much pleased in observing the style in which the work upon the Canal has been executed. It is certainly a great work, but whether of proportional utility is yet to be ascertained— The new system of Rail-roads is taking the place of Canals, and the horse can hold no competition with the locomotive.

26. VIII. Monday.— The Chief Clerk of the Custom House at New York, called on me to explain the situation of the Clerks in respect to their compensation— He referred to the act of the 2d of March 1833—the general Appropriation Act of the last Session, in the 3d. Section of which the compensation of the Collectors, Naval Officers, Surveyors, Guagers, Weighers and Measurers, are fixed as they were before the Tariff-Act of 14. July 1832. but without any provision made for the Clerks He said he had applied to Mr Webster, as Chairman of the Committee of Finance of the Senate, to get the Clerks included in the Appropriation Bill, in the amendment expected to be introduced in the Bill to continue to the Collectors, and other Officers of the customs, the provision of the last Session— At the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, the Speaker placed H. Hubbard in the Chair— It was the day for receiving Petitions and Memorials. First Charles A Barnitz of Pennsylvania made a Speech on a Memorial from the County of York, in favour of the restoration of the deposites, and the renewal of the Charter of the United States Bank, presented last Monday— Barnitz moved the reference of the Memorial to the Committee of Ways and Means, with instructions to report against the removal of the deposites and a Bill to recharter the Bank— The further consideration of this motion was postponed till next Monday.— Then George Loyall succeeded with a Speech against a memorial from his Constituents— Then Samuel F. Vinton made a distress Speech upon a Memorial, from the Counties of Washington and Athens, Ohio, presented by him last Monday— It was at his motion referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, who have before them the Bill for regulating the deposites in the local Banks— James M Bell, followed with a speech upon a similar memorial from the County of Belmont, Ohio, presented last Monday and now ordered to lie on the table— Then a Memorial from Wayne County, Indiana, presented last Monday by Jonathan M’Carty, was postponed till next Monday, and then Franklin E. Plummer made two Speeches upon memorials from two several Counties in the State of Mississippi, one against and one for the Bank— After which sundry Resolutions were offered— Ward moved the printing of 5000 copies extra of the Report of the Military Committee in favour of the continuance of the Academy at West Point. Sundry motions were made for the printing of extra copies of the Bank investigation Committees Reports—30,000—15000—10.000—25000 were the numbers proposed and Briggs moved that both Reports should be so printed as to make one pamphlet. Then the States were called through for Petitions, beginning with Maine, but they were not very numerous— There were sundry Bank and Anti-Bank Memorials— Tristam Burges presented five Resolutions of the House of Representatives of the State of Rhode-Island, against the removal of the deposites and in favour of the United States Bank— But the Senate did not concur in the Resolutions— They were postponed for consideration till next Monday—a Message from the President received last Thursday was now read— It communicated papers relating to claims of descendants and heirs of Count Rochambeau and the Baron de Kalb, for revolutionary Services, and was referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs. The House adjourned at half past three— I went into the Senate chamber and heard an argument from Mr Clayton of Delaware on the Resolution, reported by the judiciary Committee of that Body, on the Bank Pension fund question— Mr Forsyth and Silas Wright made short replies, and the questions were taken on three Resolutions declaring the Acts of 1828 and 1832. to be pension Laws, and that the Secretary of War had no authority to withdraw the funds for paying Pensions from the United States Bank and its branches.
27. V:30. Tuesday.

Mr Kervand came again to consult me concerning the debts due to him by Baron Stackelberg and George Krehmer, and the means for obtaining payment— He left with me a Letter from C. Hughes discouraging as to the prospect of his recovering the debt from Stackelberg, and shewed
me several Notes from Krehmer acknowledging his debt. I promised to see and speak with the Secretary of State— Called at the Branch Bank, and gave an order for 3000 dollars on the Branch Bank at Boston, payable 2. June— At the House, the contested Kentucky Election was the order of the day, but sundry Reports and Bills not in order were taken up by indulgence of the House— Wise made a Report from the Select Committee on the York-town Memorial for a Monument, with a Bill—twice read, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Miller called up his Resolution to print separately the two Bank Committee Reports; and Briggs called for the yeas and nays on his proposed amendment— A debate of 3 hours ensued; after which Miller accepted the amendment of Briggs—30000 copies of the whole were ordered to be printed after indignation Speeches and Counter Speeches by H. L. Pinckney, Bynum, Lytle, Sutherland, Coulter, and T. Chilton— An old motion of Hawes for reconsideration of a vote referring the commutation pension-Bill, to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union for Amendment the Bill being at the third reading was after debate rejected by yeas and nays 76 to 104. Then the foreign silver coin tender Bill was taken up on its passage, and after much debate referred to a Committee of the whole on the Union, with Instructions to report the same with an Amendment offered by B. Gorham, as a substitute Bill— This motion prevailed by yeas and nays 86 to 82— The House went into Committee, G. M Briggs in the Chair— The Bill was immediately reported to the House according to the Instructions, ordered to the 3d. reading and passed— Adjourned after 5.— I received at the House two Letters introductory of Viscount Powerscourt and Mr Parnell.
28. V:30. Wednesday.

Wrote to my Son Charles, and also to the Committee of Arrangements for the festival on the 31st of this month at Fredericksburg. Called at Gadsby’s and saw Lord Powerscourt and Mr Parnell.— At the House, I asked the Speaker Stevenson, if under the rule of the House he could introduce Strangers into the Lobby— He said yes— He told me that he was very unwell, and was about to undergo an operation for a fistula— Soon after the Meeting of the House he placed H. Hubbard in the Chair— With leave of the House I moved that the use of the Hall should be granted for a meeting in behalf of the exiled Poles, to-morrow Evening, and it was granted. The meeting failed on Monday, from the weather— Several reports of Committees were received, among which a Bill with a Report from the Committee on the Judiciary, to refund Matthew Lyon’s Sedition Law fine, to his Heirs and Representatives. N. 498. and it was referred to the Committee of the whole, who have already before them a Bill of the same complexion for the relief of Thomas Cooper 485. The contested Kentucky election followed— Vanderpoel of New-York, and Pope of Kentucky made successive Speeches, each of an hour, in favour of Moore. Then Amos Davis, a speech of two hours against Moore and the Report of the Committee— Then Jones of Georgia replied and offered an Amendment to the Amendment proposed by Banks; and after speaking till four O’Clock moved to adjourn, which motion was carried— In the Evening I had a visit from Franklin Litchfield, Consul of the United States, at Porto Caballo in Venezuela, and had a long Conversation with him on the present Condition of that Country— The Republic of Colombia is dissolved, and its very name is extinct— It forms three Independent States—Venezuela—New-Grenada, and Equador. Each recognising the two others as separate and Sovereign States— There is not the remotest prospect of their ever being united together again— Mr Litchfield says the Government of Venezuela, acknowledges as the Treaty of the Republic of Colombia with the United States as binding upon them— So do the Governments of New-Grenada and of Equador— This inability of South-America, to live united under one Government is ominous.

29. V. Thursday.— At the Meeting of the House, I asked its unanimous consent to offer three Resolutions, which I propose to move as Amendment to the Resolutions proposed by the Majority of the Bank investigating Committee, and to my great surprize they were received without objection, and ordered to be printed— The House transcended far and wide its legitimate constitutional authority in the Powers which it gave to the Bank inquisition Committee as it should have been called— The President and Directors of the United States Bank, stood upon their rights, and refused to submit to the Scrutiny of the Committee, the members of which were of course obliged to slink back with their errand unexecuted, and to relieve themselves with a petulant report of invective against the President and Directors, of the Bank and closing with a Resolution that they should be brought to the Bar of the House to answer for a contempt— The House will not dare to pass this Resolution, from which even the British Parliament would shrink abashed— I determined to put upon the Records of the House my Protest against the adoption of any such Resolution, and my indignation at the mere proposition of such measures— Boon’s Resolution for adjourning on the 16th of June, postponed for consideration to this day was next taken up, and debated till four O’Clock— Polk asked Boon to change his day to the 30th. of June; which he declined— Parker of New-Jersey moved the 23d. of June, and Horace Everett the 7th. of July— The two longest terms, were rejected by yeas and nays—the 7th. of July 28 to 172—the 30th. of June 96 to 109.— Wise moved to lay the Resolution on the table—which was rejected 65 to 141— Then Boon agreed to take the 23d. but the 16th. was still insisted on by the opposition Members and a part of the others. Clayton moved to reconsider the vote, by which the 30th. of June had been rejected; and Speight called for the previous question which was carried— Then the vote to reconsider was 122 to 84. and the final vote for the 30th. of June 129 to 83— I voted first against the 30th. of June, for the chance of a shorter day, and finally for it, to exclude a longer one—and assigned these reasons to the House for my change of vote— After the adjournment of the House, I went into the Library, and consulted the four Volumes of Precedents of cases in the House of Commons, for Parliamentary Law— Upon this doctrine of contempts, I examined also, the Register of Congressional debates. 8. 2. 2597. 1. Wilson 299. case of Alexander Murray 14— East. Sir Francis Burdett. 1. Lord Raymond 10. 18 2. 938. 115. Holt. Knollys Paty—Constitution of Maryland §12. 4. Cranch 93. Starkie on Slander 479. Constitution U.S. 5th. Amendment— 1. Chitty’s Blackstone p. 164. 3. Dallas 386. Ex post facto laws 1. Maule and Selwyn 273. 6. Wheaton 204. Anderson and Dunn— I walked home and indiscreetly fed upon Strawberries and Cream, and cherries— Invitation from Sir Charles R Vaughan to dine with him next Saturday.

30. VI. Friday— About one in the morning after three restless hours in bed, I was seized with extremely violent cramps in both legs; which forced me out of bed, and to the immediate use of a Seidlitz Powder.— I then became more composed, and got three or four hours of Sleep. But the morning was idleness and despondency— At the House just after ten—few members there. I went into the Library, and consulted 6. Wheaton, and Lord Raymond for the doctrine of contempts— I found the House in Session—and met at the door Mr Stevenson, the Speaker, who had placed H. Hubbard in the Chair; and he told me that he had just given notice that he should resign the Chair next Monday— Chilton moved a suspension of the rules to offer a Resolution for meeting during the remainder of the Session at ten in the morning, and taking a daily recess from 2 to 4. O’Clock— Suspension rejected by yeas and nays 59 to 87. The contested Kentucky Election was taken up— The Resolution reported by the Majority of the Committee of Elections assigns the Seat to Thomas P. Moore— Mr Banks moved as an Amendment
that certain votes excluded by the Committee ought to be counted. He accepted an amendment proposed by S. Jones, and modified his Resolution, to embrace the names of a number of individuals voters. Robert P. Letcher then addressed the House, in support of his claim— When the first hour expired the Speaker announced the order of the day for private business, but upon a general call from all quarters of the House, Letcher continued till 3. O’Clock, with a strong argument, earnest and good humoured— The house then adjourned to give time for preparation to Mr Moore— I went into the Senate, where they were debating a Bill for giving Land to a manual labour College in Indiana— In the Library I looked at Guthrie’s translation of the second Philippic of Cicero, much to my dissatisfaction— Then walked and rode home. My Son John was abroad at dinner time— Received a dozen copies of the 3d. Edition of Dermot MacMorrogh, printed at Columbus in Ohio.
31. VI:30. Saturday.

Planted half a dozen ripe Strawberries, to raise plants from the seeds. Mr Barnes, whom I formerly knew, called on me with Mr Bell a member of the House of Representatives from the State of Ohio— At the House. C. F. Mercer from the Committee on Roads and Canals, reported a Bill, to authorize examinations, surveys, and estimates, for the construction of roads, and the improvement of certain rivers and harbours. N. 502. read twice, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— John Bell of Tennessee Chairman of the judiciary Committee, reported a Bill giving the consent of Congress to a Convention, for the settlement of the boundaries on Hudson’s River between the States of New-York and New-Jersey— The Bill was read twice, and Mr Bell urged that it should be immediately engrossed and passed— I proposed that it should be postponed a few days and printed— The Convention affirms the exclusive jurisdiction to the respective States, and the Bill contains no reservation of the right of jurisdiction of the United States. The bill was postponed till next Wednesday and is to be printed— Kentucky contested election. Thomas P Moore made his Speech of three hours in support of his claim, and when he had closed, Leavitt of Ohio made a Speech, and upon being interrupted by Marshall of Kentucky moved the previous Question.— Tellers were called to ascertain if there was a second to the motion, and it failed 58 to 102— Upon which Hardin opened with a Speech— He was followed by M’Kinley who presented certain new views of the subject. Before he commenced, I moved at half past four an adjournment which was rejected by yeas and nays 81 to 121. After M’Kinley had finished Chilton Allen moved again to adjourn—rejected 92 to 106— Then he moved a Call of the House and 213 members answered to their names.— Excuses received from 19. Beardsley again moved the previous question again rejected. I wrote a note of excuse to Sir Charles R Vaughan, and sent it with one from Archer by my Coachman, with orders not to return— The House sat till 9 O’Clock, taking a series of questions by yeas and nays, upon all the amendments moved by Mr Banks— The yeas and nays were taken five times; and all Banks’s Amendments were carried by majorities from 8 to 20 votes, till it came to the last, the question upon which was arrested by a motion of Muhlenberg to adjourn which was carried— It was now ascertained, that the result of the amendments adopted by the House must be to declare Letcher duly elected, and Muhlenberg’s object was to concert out of the House, means to escaped from this conclusion. I walked home 10. P.M— It had rained almost the whole day.

Day. My way of Life is uniform. consumed in daily attendance at the House of Representatives writing and reading two or three hours of the morning, but as the Summer advances I have ceased to write in the Evening— Our whist parties have also ceased. The excursion to Harper’s Ferry, has furnished a pleasant Episode for this month.
